author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: Break Out the S’mores: This Star Is Cooler Than a Campfire
description: Researchers recently discovered the coldest star ever found that emits radio waves.
content: When you sit at a campfire and look up at the stars, even the tiniest pinpricks of light that you see are massive furnaces, producing intense heat. But hidden among these infernal embers are celestial bodies so dim that they’re invisible to the naked eye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Aspartame Is a Possible Cause of Cancer in Humans, a W.H.O. Agency Says
description: The F.D.A. and the powerful beverage industry protested the new findings, and a second W.H.O. group stood by its standard that the sweetener is generally safe.
content: A World Health Organization agency declared on Thursday that aspartame, an artificial sweetener widely used in diet drinks and low-sugar foods, could possibly cause cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
title: Looming U.S. Investment Restrictions on China Threaten Diplomatic Outreach
description: Any such restrictions are expected to anger Beijing and will be the first test of the new channels of communication that the world’s two largest economies are trying to restore.
content: Efforts to ease tensions between the United States and China through a series of diplomatic visits to Beijing could be undermined as the White House presses ahead with plans to impose new restrictions on American investments in Chinese companies involved in quantum computing, artificial intelligence and semiconductors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: When Spider-Man Met Jeff Koons
description: Our critic spots references to Hilma af Klint and Lichtenstein in “Across the Spider-Verse.” Koons, who inspired the film’s creative team, gets top billing with an animated survey (before his work is destroyed).
content: “Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse,” the sequel to the 2018 reimagining of the arachnid-adolescent superhero, doubles down on the first installment with an inventive and magpie visual style. The result is, at least in part, a crash course in art history (literally so, as characters frequently crash into works of art).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: 4 People Injured as ‘Severe Turbulence’ Rocks Flight to Florida
description: Two passengers and two flight attendants were injured on an Allegiant flight from North Carolina to Florida, the airline said.
content: It is a circumstance that many air travelers have feared: an airplane jolting so intensely that it sends coffee cups flying and passengers hanging in midair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil Prices Projected Higher on Supply Cuts by Saudi Arabia and Russia
description: Prices have been creeping higher, despite uncertainty about the strength of the global economy.
content: The series of oil output cuts orchestrated by Saudi Arabia since last fall may finally be having an impact on prices. Markets had largely ignored those moves, focusing instead on the shaky global economy, but this week the price of Brent crude, the international benchmark, rose above $80 a barrel for the first time since late April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling on Barbie and Kenergy
description: How do you make dolls with a thorny history into modern movie characters? Run toward the complexity, say the star-producer and her castmate.
content: Mining a cultural artifact like Barbie can be treacherous. Hew too close to the original material and you’re considered reductive. Stray too far and you’re disrespectful. Add in the fact that Barbie is one of the best known — and most problematic — brands in the world and it’s easy to see how it could all go so wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Elina Svitolina Aims for a Wimbledon Singles Final Against Jabeur or Sabalenka
description: Svitolina, the Ukrainian player who has captivated Wimbledon fans, beat No. 1 Iga Swiatek and will play Marketa Vondrousova in a semifinal match Thursday.
content: Ons Jabeur still cannot bring herself to watch last year’s Wimbledon final. Her loss to Elena Rybakina on Centre Court is still too raw, too depressing to offset any tactical value that Jabeur might squeeze out of relieving it all over again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Mary Ann Hoberman, 92, Dies; Her Rhymes Tantalized Young Readers
description: She wrote whimsical tales about the little things in a child’s life. “A House Is a House for Me” won a National Book Award.
content: Mary Ann Hoberman, whose dozens of rhyme-filled books for children sought to encourage them to read — especially to read aloud — and to commit poems to memory, died on July 7 at her home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In a Texas City, Heat Proved Deadly Even for Those Long Used to It
description: Extreme heat killed 10 people in Laredo, a sign that the eventual death toll from this year’s widespread heat waves could be substantial.
content: Alfredo Garza Jr. died in his bedroom with two broken air-conditioners, on a downtown street in Laredo, Texas, across from a coffee shop and a bakery. When his body was found, the temperature inside the room was 106 degrees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Risk of Excessive Rain Returns to the Northeast
description: As people in the Northeast continue to recover from the floods this week, the forecast calls for more rain Thursday.
content: More flooding isn’t certain, but it is possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: U.S. to Pay $975,000 to Resolve Sexual Assault Claims Against Air Force General
description: Kathryn A. Spletstoser, a retired U.S. Army colonel, had accused Gen. John E. Hyten of unwanted sexual advances and touching. General Hyten, who was later vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, denied the allegations.
content: The federal government has agreed to pay a retired Army colonel $975,000 to resolve a lawsuit she filed in 2019 that accused John E. Hyten, an Air Force general who later became vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, of sexual assault, according to court records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Oleksandr Chubko
title: Bucha gets a remake, but pain lingers behind the facade.
description: There is a line of tidy houses on Vokzalna Street, where crumbling homes once lined a roadway littered with burned-out Russian tanks. There are neat sidewalks and fresh pavement with blue and yellow bunting hanging overhead. And there are backhoes and bulldozers plowing across a construction site where a new home goods store will replace a previous one that was burned to the ground.
content: There is a line of tidy houses on Vokzalna Street, where crumbling homes once lined a roadway littered with burned-out Russian tanks. There are neat sidewalks and fresh pavement with blue and yellow bunting hanging overhead. And there are backhoes and bulldozers plowing across a construction site where a new home goods store will replace a previous one that was burned to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Laura Trethewey couldn’t have known while she was writing it that her book “The Deepest Map” — about efforts to expand human knowledge of the unexplored ocean — would arrive amid a frenzy of interest in the Titan submersible and its tragic fate. But Trethewey’s book doesn’t need the news cycle to hold anyone’s attention: It raises fascinating questions about science, technology, business and the purposes of exploration. For a perfect match of setting and subject, why not read that one at the beach?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: This Agency Was Created With a Terrorism Focus. Now It Also Has to Care for Migrants.
description: Customs and Border Protection was set up after 9/11 amid the fight against terrorism. Its responsibilities have ballooned with the influx of asylum-seeking migrants crossing the southern border.
content: On a 90-degree day in early May, hundreds of migrants were gathered on American soil near a border gate in El Paso. Many had waited for days, without food, shelter or enough water and bathrooms, before Border Patrol agents allowed them through the gate and took them to holding facilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: What to Know About the Actors’ Strike
description: Here’s why Hollywood is facing its first industrywide shutdown in more than 60 years, and what it could mean for your favorite shows.
content: The union representing more than 150,000 television and movie actors announced Thursday that it would go on strike at midnight, joining screenwriters who walked out in May and creating Hollywood’s first industrywide shutdown in 63 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Hirschfeld
title: A Perfect Weekend in Telluride
description: Well known for its ski resort, this mountain town in southwestern Colorado attracts plenty of summer and fall visitors, too. Here’s how to spend a few days.
content: “This view is, like, killer,” I overheard a 20-something say to his companions during a recent visit to Telluride. We had just walked by each other on the main street of this southwestern Colorado mountain town, wedged into a box canyon. The group was looking toward the vertiginous cliffs high above, where Ingram Falls plunged over a notch in the rock; below the falls, a thread of water followed a steep, diagonal runnel, glinting silver, like the precious metal miners once sought here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Pledges Long-Term Backing for Ukraine, but a U.S. Election Looms
description: Citing American politics, some NATO leaders expressed concern that Washington could waver in its support if there were a shift in power.
content: Moments after President Biden assured Volodymyr Zelensky that he could count on United States support for as long as it took, the Ukrainian leader used the opportunity to speak not only to NATO allies but also to an audience thousands of miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: A Rocket Alternative to SpaceX Inches Toward Its First Launch
description: United Launch Alliance said on Thursday that it was still planning the first flight of the Vulcan rocket before the end of this year after a problem during prelaunch testing.
content: Building a rocket is difficult. Preparing a new rocket for its first flight is even more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Final Cut’ Review: A Feeble Rise of the Living Dead
description: A remake of a Japanese zom-com, this French adaptation about the making of a B-level zombie flick does little to justify its existence.
content: If you’re going to remake a film whose footprint is still fresh, you better make it your own if not significantly better. The French zom-com “Final Cut” does neither — the veteran filmmaker Michel Hazanavicius (“The Artist”) may have an Oscar, but his uninspired riff on the Japanese movie “One Cut of the Dead” (2019) has got nothing on the original’s ultra-low-budget charms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Two Tickets to Greece’ Review: Advisory Travel
description: Former middle-school friends with clashing temperaments take an Aegean excursion in this contrived French fluff.
content: In “Two Tickets to Greece,” Blandine (Olivia Côte), a depressed and divorced Frenchwoman, is pushed by her son to take a Hellenic excursion with Magalie (Laure Calamy), the middle-school best friend she lost touch with decades earlier. Magalie, now a free-spirited, impulsive music journalist, can find fun anywhere. Blandine, a buttoned-up radiology technician embittered by her ex-husband’s remarriage, seems incapable of experiencing fun at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
title: Prosecutors Ask Witnesses Whether Trump Acknowledged He Lost 2020 Race
description: Jared Kushner was questioned before a federal grand jury as prosecutors appeared to be trying to establish if the former president knew his efforts to stay in power were built on a lie.
content: Federal prosecutors investigating former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election have questioned multiple witnesses in recent weeks — including Mr. Trump’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner — about whether Mr. Trump had privately acknowledged in the days after the 2020 election that he had lost, according to four people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Flash Floods Soak Parts of Mississippi
description: The National Weather Service in Jackson, Miss., issued several flash-flood warnings as heavy rains drenched the state on Thursday.
content: Heavy rains led to road closures and several flash-flood warnings in Mississippi on Thursday, a day after warnings were issued for parts of Arkansas and Louisiana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Russian General Denounces His Bosses as Officers Are Fired or Questioned
description: The Wagner group mutiny three weeks ago has exposed dissension and fueled a shake-up in the Russian military, as it tries to fend off a Ukrainian advance.
content: A top Russian general in Ukraine has lashed out at his bosses after being fired from his command, accusing them of undermining the war effort with dishonesty and politicking, in the latest sign of turmoil within the Kremlin’s military leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody García, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Simon Romero
title: Insurgent Party Can Stay on Guatemala’s Ballot, Election Agency Says
description: A prosecutor had tried to suspend the party, knocking the anticorruption presidential candidate Bernardo Arévalo out of next month’s runoff contest.
content: Guatemala’s electoral authority on Thursday rejected efforts by a top prosecutor to suspend the party of a surging anticorruption candidate, which would have upended the presidential election and dealt a severe blow to the country’s already fraying democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Notley and Anne Boyer
title: Poem: Peridots of Kings
description: A postapocalyptic landscape and a stark view of the present, hollowed out but for the corporate interests.
content: Alice Notley’s “Peridots of Kings” is a poem set in what would be a postapocalyptic landscape, but this is not the landscape of some grimly imagined future. It is, instead, a stark view of the present, hollowed out but for the corporate interests; bearing history, but void of culture. The desert theater in ruins. The tenses mix up; time scatters. What is it to be a poet in a world that appears to yawn in indifference, in a society in which the reader no longer seems to need a poet or a self — needs, instead, only “a big store”? The poem is a question, but it is also its own answer — one that is haunting, feral. Selected By Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Bipartisan Measure Aims to Force Release of U.F.O. Records
description: Legislation backed by Chuck Schumer, the Senate majority leader, would create a review board to declassify documents related to unidentified aerial phenomena across the government.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the majority leader, is pushing legislation to create a commission with broad authority to declassify government documents about U.F.O.s and extraterrestrial matters, in an attempt to force the government to share all that it knows about unidentified phenomena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Mets Hope to ‘Keep This Thing Afloat’ in the Second Half
description: The Mets are facing an 18-game stretch that could make or break the club. “The better we play, the longer we stay together,” Francisco Lindor said.
content: The Los Angeles Dodgers arrive at Citi Field on Friday to start the second half of the baseball season. The visit is the first test in a crucial 15-game run for the Mets that will take the team to the Aug. 1 trading deadline — and determine its future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Khalil Gibran Muhammad
title: How Hubert Humphrey Tried to Make Minneapolis, and America, Less Racist
description: In “Into the Bright Sunshine,” Samuel G. Freedman makes the case that Humphrey was part of the vanguard in the fight for civil rights.
content: Minneapolis may be the city most notorious for anti-Black police violence in the world. In 2020, following the murder of George Floyd by the police officer Derek Chauvin, tens of millions of people across the United States protested for civil rights in a city once considered a national model of racial liberalism, in a state whose citizens are thought to be “Minnesota Nice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: A French Festival Focuses (Timidly) on English
description: The Avignon Festival’s new director wants to spotlight drama in a different language each year. This year’s first installment had some conventional choices.
content: As soon as the Portuguese director Tiago Rodrigues took over at the Avignon Festival, France’s biggest theater event, he announced a symbolic move: Under his direction, there would be a special focus on a different language every year, starting, this summer, with English.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and Cade Metz
title: F.T.C. Opens Investigation Into ChatGPT Maker Over Technology’s Potential Harms
description: The agency sent OpenAI, which makes ChatGPT, a letter this week over consumer harms and the company’s security practices.
content: The Federal Trade Commission has opened an investigation into OpenAI, the artificial intelligence start-up that makes ChatGPT, over whether the chatbot has harmed consumers through its collection of data and its publication of false information on individuals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Everything’s Coming Up Soft Landing
description: Inflation seems to be fading without a recession.
content: The latest numbers on consumer prices arrived on Wednesday, and they were better than even optimists had expected. Even media reports, as far I can tell, generally omitted the “but concerns remain” qualifiers that have seemed mandatory when covering good news about the Biden economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Texas TikTok Ban Challenged for Threatening ‘Academic Freedom’
description: A lawsuit filed on Thursday says Gov. Greg Abbott’s ban is compromising research and teaching at public universities.
content: A ban of TikTok on state devices and networks in Texas was challenged by First Amendment lawyers on Thursday, who said the law violated the Constitution by limiting research and teaching at public universities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: New York Is Ordered by Appeals Court to Redraw House Map
description: The decision, if upheld, could allow Democrats to shift as many as six G.O.P.-held seats in their direction. Republicans vowed to appeal.
content: A New York appeals court on Thursday ordered the state’s congressional map to be redrawn, siding with Democrats in a case that could give the party a fresh chance to tilt one of the nation’s most contested House battlegrounds leftward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Democrats, It’s OK to Talk About Hunter Biden
description: In fact, it’s necessary — and so is being honest about his father.
content: If you travel in predominantly Democratic circles and want to have a really trying day, write or publicly say something unflattering but true about President Biden, a lament legible or audible beyond people who can be safely depended on to vote for him. Then brace for the furies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: ‘The Summer I Turned Pretty’: Lola Tung on Growing Up Alongside Belly
description: Tung has experienced a lot of changes since joining Amazon’s hit coming-of-age series at 18. It’s just one way her life mirrors that of her character.
content: Lola Tung was taking classes as a first-year acting student at Carnegie Mellon University, in Pittsburgh, when she heard the news. She had just been selected to play the lead in a new Amazon series called “The Summer I Turned Pretty,” based on the best-selling young adult novel by Jenny Han.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Black Ice’ Review: A Troubled Hockey History
description: The Canadian filmmaker Hubert Davis amplifies the voices of hockey players of color and reveals the sport’s lesser-known pioneers in this smart, sensitive documentary.
content: Hubert Davis’s “Black Ice” candidly and sensitively recounts the experiences of athletes of color in Canadian hockey, and racism endured at the hands of other players, coaches and fans. Letting the athletes speak for themselves, Davis balances infuriating and painful accounts of their experiences with a look at the extraordinary legacy of Canadian hockey players of color, which dates back to the Colored Hockey League founded in the 19th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Jin Yu Young
title: How Netflix Plans Total Global Domination, One Korean Drama at a Time
description: Popular content produced in Asia and around the world has taken on greater significance with most of Hollywood now on strike.
content: They met in a 20th-floor conference room in Seoul named for one successful project with Korean talent — “Okja,” a 2017 film of one girl’s devotion to a genetically modified super pig — to discuss what they hoped would become another hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Afire’ Review: His Flaws Are Petty, Pathetic and Funny
description: Christian Petzold’s new film, about a sour young writer and the woman he desires, generates both cruel comedy and heartbreak.
content: The German filmmaker Christian Petzold’s spiky and at times mordantly funny “Afire” is a tonic for moviegoers tired of nice, squishable, likable, relatable dull and dull characters. It’s a look — for starters — at a splenetic young writer who, during a stay in the country, waits for his publisher to weigh in on his unfortunately titled second novel “Club Sandwich.” He frets that it’s no good, though his arrogance is sturdier and more consuming than his doubts. Yet while the writer is boorish, he’s never insipid; he’s pleasurably bad company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell, Richard Beaven and Hilary Swift
title: Vermont Storm Exposes the Strengths, and Limits, of New Flood Defenses
description: The state began new flood protection efforts after being battered by Tropical Storm Irene in 2011. Many appeared to be effective, but experts say more will be needed as storms become more extreme.
content: Vermont, a state known for peaceful green mountains, grazing cows and tidy covered bridges, is not often seen as a place where mudslides threaten highways, rivers churn with debris and murky, propane-fouled floodwaters fill downtown streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Brooding Sorts
description: Hanh Huynh makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Compounding Disasters
description: America’s compounding natural disasters show the reality of climate change.
content: Extreme weather suddenly seems to be happening everywhere at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: The Artist’s Wounded Heart
description: At the New Museum, Pepón Osorio’s exhilarating assemblages and installations hold a mirror up to Latino communities and reflect his experiences in Puerto Rico and New York.
content: “My mother used to be a baker. My work consists of pouring out knowledge which I gained in the midst of my family. They are very creative people. They used to bake some incredible productions: fountains … sugar … dolls … oceans.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: ‘And Just Like That …’ Style Recap: Going as Yourself for Halloween
description: In the fifth episode of the season, Carrie and her friends dress up for a costume benefit, and Rock gets scouted by Ralph Lauren.
content: This article contains spoilers for Episode 5 of the second season of “And Just Like That …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Surviving Extreme Heat
description: A dispatch from Phoenix.
content: “Like being on the edge of death if you go for a walk.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Carlos Alcaraz, Daniil Medvedev and the Power of Vulnerability
description: Alcaraz and Medvedev rarely shy away from discussing their frailties, reflecting a shift in tennis culture. Now, they’ll face off in a Wimbledon semifinal.
content: Carlos Alcaraz is nearly always a killer on the court, suffocating opponents with relentless aggressiveness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: You Didn’t Have to Be Famous to Be Buried at Green-Wood
description: The Brooklyn cemetery also contains “public lots” — final resting places for those without wealth or status.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at an artist who focused on less-than-famous sections of a famous cemetery in Brooklyn. We’ll also find out why some officials consider City Hall’s reaction to last month’s wildfire smoke sluggish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Hollywood Is Shutting Down
description: Also, the first nonprescription birth control pill. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: The union representing more than 160,000 television and movie actors announced today that its members were going on strike after negotiations with the major Hollywood studios over a new contract collapsed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Crypto Industry Secures Early Victory in Legal Battle With Regulators
description: A judge ruled that the sale of the cryptocurrency XRP on public exchanges did not violate securities law.
content: The cryptocurrency industry secured an early victory in its court battle with U.S. regulators when a federal judge ruled on Thursday that the sale on public exchanges of a digital asset called XRP complied with securities laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Charles M. Blow
title: Tommy Tuberville Is Whitewashing White Nationalism
description: White nationalism was fundamental to the creation of America. That fact doesn’t change because it makes some uncomfortable.
content: In an interview in May, the senior Republican senator from Alabama, Tommy Tuberville — who is holding up hundreds of promotions for senior military officers because he disagrees with a Defense Department policy that facilitates abortion access for service members — was asked if he believes white nationalists should be allowed in the military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mathew Brownstein
title: School’s Out, but Education News Churns On
description: Stephanie Saul, a national education reporter, shares what she’s been hearing on college campuses, even in the summer months.
content: Education in the United States has been at the forefront of the news cycle: Last month, the Supreme Court ruled on affirmative action, deciding to end race-conscious college admissions, and blocked President Biden’s student loan forgiveness plan. Then, there’s the ongoing debate in elementary and high schools over book bans and how — or even if — gender, sexuality and race should be taught. Even the high school theater stage has become a political battleground, as some parents and school officials try to control what plays can be staged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Lightning Can Strike, but It Can’t Hide From a New Satellite
description: A powerful new European weather orbiter’s cameras capture lightning in near real-time at day or night across more than 80 percent of the world’s surface.
content: Lightning comes and goes in brilliant and terrifying flashes. With powerful enough satellites in orbit, all that crackling static in the world’s skies is being brought into view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Tucker and Petra Epperlein
title: Artists, Plumbers, Bakers and Five Days to Make Them Soldiers
description: Ukrainian citizen-soldiers are in a fight for survival — and they don’t have time to travel for training.
content: Michael Dumler, an American photographer, went to Ukraine to document the war. But when he arrived, he put down his camera and dedicated himself to addressing a more pressing need: training ordinary Ukrainians how to fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Claire Moses
title: A Sriracha Shortage? It Depends Which Brand You’re Looking For.
description: Huy Fong Foods is having production issues for the second year in a row, causing some people to pay high prices on eBay. Other hot sauce makers are seizing the moment.
content: Every month, Jimmy Ly usually orders nearly 150 bottles of sriracha from Huy Fong Foods for one of his Vietnamese restaurants in New York City. The sauce opens the richness of a pho broth or adds a blast of heat to a banh xeo, a Vietnamese crepe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Carlo Vittorini, Publisher Who Lifted Parade Magazine, Dies at 94
description: He spent two decades guiding a popular newspaper Sunday supplement as its revenue and circulation grew, reaching nearly 40 million readers at one point.
content: Carlo Vittorini, who as publisher guided Parade magazine, the nearly ubiquitous weekly Sunday newspaper supplement, to revenue and circulation heights, died on June 25 at his summer home in Nantucket, Mass. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Texas A&M Celebrated a New Journalism Director. Then Came the Complaints.
description: Kathleen McElroy was appointed head of a journalism program at the university. But then her work in D.E.I. seemed to come into question.
content: Kathleen McElroy, who had recently served as the director of the University of Texas’s School of Journalism, was thrilled to embark on a new assignment: running a similar program at her alma mater, Texas A&M University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein
title: Founder of Bankrupt Crypto Firm Celsius Is Arrested on Fraud Charges
description: Alex Mashinsky was arrested on Thursday morning. He and his former firm also face lawsuits from the Securities and Exchange Commission and other regulators.
content: Alex Mashinsky, the founder and former chief executive of the bankrupt cryptocurrency firm Celsius Network, was arrested on Thursday and charged with defrauding customers and lying about his firm’s business model.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Secret Service Closes White House Cocaine Case Without Any Suspects
description: The agency said there was no surveillance video footage that provided concrete leads to identify who may have left the bag in the White House’s guest lobby.
content: The Secret Service said on Thursday that it had closed its investigation into how cocaine ended up in the guest lobby of the West Wing after security video failed to provide any leads and no fingerprints were found on the bag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Schoenfeld
title: She’s Got the Hardest Job in Soccer. Can She Keep Winning?
description: A former World Cup winner, Cindy Parlow Cone is now working to help America realize its global soccer ambitions. Her legacy may be defined by a few games.
content: A meeting of the Fédération Internationale de Football Association, the governing body for world soccer, is an impressive professional gathering of “older men wearing ties,” as Gijs de Jong, who oversees the Royal Netherlands Football Association, describes it. The head of Mexico’s football federation is a former television executive who ran sports at Univision for a decade. Greece’s federation is led by the legal-and-political adviser to a former prime minister. The chairman of the Swedish Football Association, Fredrik Reinfeldt, actually is a former prime minister. The president of England’s Football Association is the Prince of Wales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Man Shot Dead by Police After a Report of Stolen Fruit
description: A New Rochelle, N.Y., police officer shot Jarrell Garris, 37, after he was accused of eating some grapes and a banana without paying, his family’s lawyer said. The police said he tried to grab an officer’s gun.
content: It’s impossible for Raymond Fowler to explain how it felt to learn a police officer shot his only son after he was accused of taking a few dollars’ worth of fruit, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Trachta
title: ‘And Just Like That …’ Season 2, Episode 5 Recap: Meet-Ugly
description: Carrie used to be looking for true love. It’s safe to say that whatever she found in this week’s episode, it was something else.
content: In the final scenes of the original “Sex and the City” series, Carrie describes herself as someone who is looking for love. “Real love,” to be specific. “Ridiculous, inconvenient, consuming, can’t-live-without-each-other love.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allie Conti and Lanna Apisukh
title: One Man’s Lonely War on Central Park Pickleball
description: Pickleball is everywhere, and “Paddleball Paul” is making his last stand on the handball courts of Central Park. It’s not going very well.
content: It was a beautiful summer Saturday in Central Park, and by late morning, the pickleballers had filled the handball courts in the North Meadow. There were six games going on simultaneously, with players laughing and fist-bumping between every point. On the sidelines were dozens more waiting their turn to play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing: Thailand in Turmoil
description: Also, an industry-wide strike in Hollywood, floods in Delhi and Netflix’s Asia strategy.
content: After the military-backed Senate rejected Pita Limjaroenrat as prime minister, Thailand was staring down what could be another intense period of political unrest and nationwide protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Legal Fights and Charges of Discrimination Send Latino Group Into Turmoil
description: A battle over Puerto Rico statehood and claims of a “takeover” are testing a 94-year-old civil rights organization known as LULAC.
content: One of the nation’s oldest and most venerated Latino civil rights organizations is at a critical juncture that some members say could determine its direction — or have dire implications for its future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: The W.H.O. Says Aspartame Is ‘Possibly Carcinogenic.’ What Does That Mean?
description: Experts say there’s no need to panic about your diet soda habit.
content: On Thursday, two World Health Organization agencies released their findings on aspartame, the artificial sweetener found in thousands of sugar-free products like diet sodas, chewing gums, yogurts and energy drinks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Have You Got It Yet?’ Review: A Pink Floyd Enigma Illuminated
description: The founding frontman of Pink Floyd, Syd Barrett was irresistibly charismatic, but this crazy diamond didn’t shine for long, as this comprehensive portrait shows.
content: The classic rock legends who died young are unfortunately numerous: Hendrix, Joplin, Cobain. Syd Barrett, a founder of Pink Floyd, lived to be 60 — hardly a ripe old age. But his artistic death, a protracted one, happened in his 20s, and he had become a recluse before he turned 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Mingle
title: Even ‘Safe’ Places Are Experiencing Climate Chaos in America
description: In Vermont, the climate is jumping the banks and blowing past the guardrails.
content: LINCOLN, Vt. — The capital of Vermont — the state that often tops those “best states to move to and avoid climate change” lists — was, until Tuesday afternoon, mostly underwater.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hua Hsu Wants to Know Who Wrote the Zine ‘Secret Asian Man’
description: “A collection of these issues would undoubtedly be my favorite book that no one has heard of,” says the author of the memoir “Stay True,” one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2022. “If you are reading this, please write me!”
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: ‘They’re Outsmarting Us’: Birds Build Nests From Anti-Bird Spikes
description: Strips of sharp metal pins are meant to keep birds away from buildings. Some birds are stealing them to build their nests.
content: Auke-Florian Hiemstra, a biologist who studies how wild animals repurpose human materials, thought he had seen everything. In his research on the common coot, a water bird often found in Dutch canals, he had discovered nests containing windshield wipers, sunglasses, plastic carnations, condoms and envelopes used to package cocaine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Breaking Up With Diet Soda? Here Are 11 Aspartame-Free Alternatives.
description: If the World Health Organization’s warning about the artificial sweetener has you worried, try these other refreshers.
content: The World Health Organization declared Thursday that the artificial sweetener aspartame is “possibly carcinogenic to humans,” adding it to the same risk category as breathing in engine exhaust, working in dry-cleaning and consuming certain pickled vegetables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
title: Junta’s Allies Reject Thai Election Results, Derailing Top Opposition Figure
description: The Thai military’s hold on the Senate blocked a popular progressive candidate who had emerged as the clear winner. Parliament will now have to vote again, as the opposition vows to demonstrate.
content: The takeaway from Thailand’s general election in May was clear: Voters had dealt a crushing blow to the ruling military junta by supporting a progressive party that challenged not only the generals but also the nation’s powerful monarchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Don’t cook dinner. Assemble it.
description: Adult Lunchables? “Girl dinner”? Whatever you call them, these vibrant platters are delicious.
content: Well into July, more and more of my meals look like this: A smattering of crackers, a small dish of edamame, maybe a mound of hummus alongside spears of Persian cucumbers, a handful of popcorn, a piece of cheese, a few blackberries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Moss and Campbell Robertson
title: Jury in Pittsburgh Synagogue Trial Finds Gunman’s Crimes Eligible for Death Penalty
description: Next, in the final phase of the federal trial, jurors will weigh whether to recommend sentencing Robert Bowers to death or to life in prison.
content: The federal trial of the man who killed 11 people in a Pittsburgh synagogue will move to its final phase next week, after the jury found on Thursday that the crimes the defendant has been convicted of committing were eligible for the death penalty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: ‘Elon Musk Is Doing for Zuckerberg What Trump Did for George W. Bush’
description: Threads and the search for our next social media home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: ‘Lakota Nation vs. United States’ Review: A 150-Year Clash
description: In 1980, the Lakota were offered money for their stolen Black Hills land. They refused to accept the settlement and continue to fight today.
content: Three years after the discovery of gold nuggets on Lakota land in 1874, the Black Hills Act stripped the tribe of most of the acreage in the Dakotas and northwestern Nebraska it had been ceded by treaty decades earlier, making way for droves of fortune-seekers. Ever since, the Lakota people have been fighting to regain that land, a plight recorded in a new documentary, “Lakota Nation vs. United States.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Banana Republic Wants to Outfit Your Home, Too
description: Responding to a volatile market for work clothes, the retailer hopes that selling home goods will help stabilize its business.
content: Inside Banana Republic’s design studio in San Francisco, Sandra Stangl, the company’s chief executive, pointed to an item that had been creating buzz in stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes, John Koblin and Nicole Sperling
title: Actors Join Writers on Strike, Bringing Hollywood to a Standstill
description: The dual walkouts pit more than 170,000 workers against old-line studios like Disney and Sony, as well as tech juggernauts like Netflix and Amazon.
content: The Hollywood actors’ union approved a strike on Thursday for the first time in 43 years, bringing the $134 billion American movie and television business to a halt over anger about pay and fears of a tech-dominated future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The A.I. Wars Heat Up as Elon Musk and Meta Enter the Ring
description: Both Musk, who once backed OpenAI, and Facebook’s parent company are set to unveil new services aimed at getting a piece of the artificial intelligence boom.
content: The rivalry between Mark Zuckerberg and Elon Musk won’t be confined to social media posts or a cage fight. The tech heavyweights are accelerating pushes into the artificial intelligence world to take on the Microsoft-backed OpenAI and Google, taking different approaches in the buzziest sector of the software industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘The Miracle Club’ Review: A Pleasant Pilgrimage
description: Set in 1967 Dublin, this mild-mannered comedy explores grief and grievances with an ensemble that includes Maggie Smith, Kathy Bates and Laura Linney.
content: A camera soars above Dublin then glides toward a promontory where a solitary figure stands in front of a memorial plaque. A frothy score wrangles our emotions. Don’t get too sad, it seems to say, before the camera closes in on a sorrowful Lily Fox (Maggie Smith).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Stella Tan, Sydney Harper, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Nina Feldman, Rachelle Bonja, Liz O. Baylen, Lisa Chow, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto, Alyssa Moxley and Chris Wood
title: How Affirmative Action Changed Their Lives
description: Three Americans discuss how their prospects were shaped by the policy and what they think about a future without it.
content: Two weeks ago, the United States Supreme Court struck down affirmative action, declaring that the race-conscious admissions programs at Harvard and the University of North Carolina were unlawful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Anchor Brewing, the Oldest Craft Brewer in the U.S., Will Close After 127 Years
description: “The stake through the heart of Anchor was the pandemic,” a company spokesman said.
content: It survived San Francisco’s devastating 1906 earthquake, Prohibition and both world wars. But recent economic pressures proved too much for the company said to be the oldest craft brewer in the country: After 127 years, Anchor Brewing Company is shutting down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen: Saving Elephants in Zambia, Serial’s New Episode, ‘The Sound of Music’
description: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
content: Hey Audio fans, hope you’re staying cool out there. We have a bounty of audio riches to get you through the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: The Martini Has Lost Its Mind
description: Ordering a dirty martini these days doesn’t guarantee gin, vermouth or even an olive — but you might get squid ink or a mozzarella ball.
content: Consider the paradoxical thought experiment known as the Ship of Theseus: If Athenians removed and replaced every plank of Theseus’s ship so that none of the original wood remained, would it still be Theseus’s ship? Or would it become a different ship entirely?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Zelensky Leaves NATO Summit to Face Hard Realities of War
description: The Ukrainian leader secured new pledges of weapons and reaffirmed security commitments from Western allies, but it was not clear how significant a boost they could provide for his country’s counteroffensive.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was traveling home on Thursday from the NATO summit, emphasizing success in his efforts to draw his country closer to the alliance, though without the firm timeline to join that he had demanded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
title: Evacuations Ordered in Delhi: Monsoon Flooding in Pictures
description: The authorities warned of widespread flooding in the Indian capital after days of torrential rains claimed dozens of lives in neighboring states.
content: Thousands of people were evacuated from their homes in Delhi on Thursday after the authorities warned of widespread flooding following days of torrential rains that have battered large swaths of northern India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Democrats Try a Novel Tactic to Revive the Equal Rights Amendment
description: Proponents of the measure to enshrine a guarantee of sex equality into the Constitution are using a creative legal theory to try to resurrect the long-stalled amendment.
content: Democrats in Congress are making a fresh push for the nearly century-old Equal Rights Amendment to be enshrined in the Constitution, rallying around a creative legal theory in a bid to revive an amendment that would explicitly guarantee sex equality as a way to protect reproductive rights in post-Roe America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Republicans Assail Kerry’s Climate Strategy as He Prepares for China Talks
description: John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, was criticized by Republicans as being too soft on China, the world’s biggest polluter.
content: Republicans on Thursday accused John Kerry, President Biden’s special envoy for climate, of being soft on China as he prepared to travel to Beijing to restart discussions between the world’s top two polluting countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Bird Box Barcelona’ Review: Blind Faith
description: The blindfolds are back in this companion movie to Susanne Bier’s 2018 original as a traumatized man finds horrifying purpose in mass slaughter.
content: In the mildly entertaining Sandra Bullock vehicle, “Bird Box,” alien invaders were presumed so fearsome to behold that all who gazed upon them immediately offed themselves. Possibly to save audiences from a similar fate, we were never permitted to see these terrors, leaving us as sightless as the movie’s scrabbling survivors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: In U.K. Court, Kevin Spacey Denies Sexual Assault Charges
description: Two weeks into a trial in London, the Oscar-winning actor gave his account of sexual encounters that the prosecution says were criminal acts.
content: Kevin Spacey told a British jury on Thursday that he was “a big flirt, ” but he denied the accusations of four men who say he sexually assaulted them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Frieze Art Fair Acquires Armory Show and Expo Chicago
description: Both fairs will continue to operate under their existing brands with their current teams.
content: Increasing its share of the art-fair market, the London-based Frieze on Thursday announced its acquisition of the Armory Show in New York, as well a signed agreement to acquire EXPO CHICAGO, two of the longest-running art fairs in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Evelyn M. Witkin, Who Discovered How DNA Repairs Itself, Dies at 102
description: Her findings led to breakthroughs in the treatment of cancer and in the understanding of the mechanics of evolution.
content: Evelyn M. Witkin, whose discovery of the process by which DNA repairs itself opened the door to significant advances in the treatment of cancer and genetic defects, died on Saturday in Plainsboro Township, N.J. She was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Johnston
title: The U.S. Still Can Do What’s Right for Haiti
description: It is long past time it stopped propping up unpopular political leaders.
content: In July 2021, a group of heavily armed men stormed the home of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti, killing him and wounding the first lady. There is still much we don’t know, but the U.S. Department of Justice has said the plot to oust him was hatched in Florida. Eleven people, including several American citizens, have been charged in relation to the conspiracy, and more than 40 people are being held — uncharged — in deplorable conditions in Haiti in connection with the crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: This week’s properties are in Prospect Heights, Morningside Heights and East Chelsea.
content: A two-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath, 1,630-square-foot duplex condo with an entry closet, a powder room, a great room with floor-to-ceiling windows, an open kitchen with a breakfast bar, and a primary suite on the upper level; and a second bedroom, full bath, home-office nook and an exit to a private rear patio on the lower level, plus a washer-dryer and deeded basement storage in a six-story building with a part-time doorman, video security, a superintendent, package room, gym, residents’ lounge, parking garage, shared garden and roof deck. Lindsay Barton Barrett, Douglas Elliman, 917-363-5521; elliman.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Klonick
title: The Future of Online Speech Shouldn’t Belong to One Trump-Appointed Judge in Louisiana
description: The politics of internet regulation have become too local.
content: No feat of rhetoric could disguise the flagrantly political nature of the federal court ruling on July 4 that restricted the Biden administration’s communications with social media platforms — but Judge Terry A. Doughty, who wrote the opinion, did his best to cover his tracks. The 155-page opinion, which could hinder the government’s efforts to counter false and misleading online speech about issues like election interference and vaccine safety, is laced with lofty references to George Orwell and quotations from Benjamin Franklin and Thomas Jefferson, making it more reminiscent of a civics essay than a federal judicial opinion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Super PAC Made $155,000 Payment to Melania Trump in 2021
description: The money was listed as pay for a “speaking engagement” by Ms. Trump in a new personal financial disclosure by her husband.
content: A super PAC aligned with former President Donald J. Trump paid Melania Trump $155,000 in late 2021, an unusual payment that was not visible in the group’s initial federal reports and came to light only in a filing by Mr. Trump on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: ‘I Never Wanted to Be Just an Offensive Player’
description: Even after he returns, Aaron Judge could have his mobility limited by his toe injury all season. That would be quite a blow for a Yankee captain who takes pride in his defense and his athleticism.
content: Eric Karros settled in behind the cage as the Yankees took batting practice before their series opener in Dodger Stadium last month. During his 14 years as a major leaguer, plus two decades since as a television analyst, he had made it a point to arrive early on the field to watch only three men hit: Barry Bonds, Mark McGwire and Giancarlo Stanton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Push Back on Trump’s Request to Delay Documents Trial
description: The office of the special counsel, Jack Smith, said there “is no basis in law or fact” for granting a motion from former President Donald J. Trump that could push the start of the trial until after Election Day.
content: Federal prosecutors on Thursday asked the judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case to reject a motion by Mr. Trump’s lawyers to have his trial indefinitely postponed, a move that could serve to delay the proceeding until after the 2024 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dawn Chan
title: Call It Dance, Puppetry or Sculpture, It Is Eerily Beautiful
description: Throughout the 21-minute arc of “Divine Generations,” a silent four-person ensemble pulls cords around the room, coaxing inert discs into motion.
content: A classic marionette might have eight to 10 strings. Leah Ogawa’s latest puppet, an ethereal tree-shaped form, has more than 600: clustered into thickets and tangles, threaded through eye bolts on the ceiling, and fanning out overhead to all corners of the room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Video Games at MoMA: Do They Belong There?
description: “Never Alone,” which closes Sunday, was an important first step in breaking the firewall between art lovers and game designers.
content: When the Museum of Modern Art began collecting video games a decade ago, curators boldly asserted that games were an artistic medium. Now contemporary culture is dominated by them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Is the New 988 Suicide Hotline Working?
description: One year in, many people still don’t know it exists — but those behind it are working to get the word out.
content: The contestants on “Celebrity Jeopardy!” were stumped in the fall when asked about the new “3-digit national hotline phone number for suicide prevention” in the United States, which debuted last July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: What the Hollywood Actors and Writers Strikes Mean for TV and Movies
description: After two months without new late-night TV shows, viewers are likely to notice the effects of the dual walkouts more broadly within the next couple of months unless agreements are reached quickly.
content: For more than two months, viewers have been without new episodes of late-night shows like “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert,” “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” and “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” because of the writers strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein and Jane Stockdale
title: Elina Svitolina’s Love Affair With Wimbledon Ends, but U.S. Open Awaits
description: Svitolina, the Ukrainian star who captured hearts in London and beyond, lost to Marketa Vondrousova on Thursday but will play on through the summer.
content: One fan in Centre Court held the Ukrainian flag. Another yelled, “We love you, Elina.” The Ukrainian ambassador was there, too, cheering along with fans from Britain, the United States, Uganda, Bulgaria and more, for Elina Svitolina, the uncrowned sentimental champion of Wimbledon 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Gabby Douglas, a Trailblazer in Gymnastics, Announces Her Return
description: “Let’s do this,” the former Olympian wrote alongside a picture of herself performing on the beam.
content: Gabby Douglas, who in 2012 became the first Black woman to win the highest individual Olympic gymnastics competition and later drew attention to the abuse perpetrated within the sport, announced on Instagram Thursday that she was returning to competitive gymnastics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Treasury Taps Sanctions Architect to Lead Financial Crimes Team
description: Andrea Gacki has played a leading role in designing sanctions that the U.S. has imposed on Russia as punishment for its invasion of Ukraine.
content: The Treasury Department said on Thursday that Andrea Gacki, an architect of the Biden administration’s sanctions program, would become the director of the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network in September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Votes to Limit Abortion Access in the Military, Bowing to the Right
description: G.O.P. leaders acceded to the demands of ultraconservatives to use the annual defense policy bill to lodge cultural grievances and protest continued U.S. support for Ukraine. Now its fate is in doubt.
content: A divided House voted on Thursday to restrict abortion access, bar transgender health services and limit diversity training for military personnel, potentially imperiling passage of the annual defense bill as Republicans, goaded by their right flank, loaded the measure with conservative policy dictates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson
title: Blinken Meets China’s Top Diplomat in Latest Bid to Ease Tensions
description: In their second meeting in less than a month, the secretary of state spoke to China’s envoy, Wang Yi, about ‘managing competition’ amid reports of a potential Chinese hack.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with China’s top diplomat, Wang Yi, on the sidelines of a regional summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, the latest in a string of diplomatic meetings between U.S. and Chinese officials as the two countries try to ease tensions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aidan Gardiner
title: How Philadelphia Kept Thousands of Tenants From Being Evicted
description: A lockdown-era program that gets landlords talking to tenants has had notable success for both. Can it continue?
content: In early February, a piece of paper slipped through the mail slot in Ivy Handy’s door. She owed her landlord $2,184.75, it said, and if she didn’t pay, she would have to leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: ‘As Long as It Takes’: Biden Adds to Talk of a New Cold War
description: But that oversimplifies a complex global situation, others say, with a weakened Russia and with China facing serious problems of its own.
content: President Biden and his national security team have contended since he took office that all the easy, tempting comparisons between this era and the Cold War are misleading, a vast oversimplification of a complex geopolitical moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
title: Butcher Who Assaulted Officers on Jan. 6 Is Sentenced to 7 Years in Prison
description: The sentence for Kyle Fitzsimons was handed down the same day a California man who placed conspiracy theories at the heart of his trial defense was convicted in connection with the Capitol attack.
content: A butcher from Maine who assaulted five police officers during the riot at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was sentenced on Thursday to more than seven years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Twitter Shows, Again, the Failure of the New Right’s Theory of Power
description: How to take something that has flaws — and break it completely.
content: If you spend much time online, you witnessed something remarkable last week. Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, introduced a competitor to Twitter called Threads, and the public response was astonishing. As my colleague Mike Isaac detailed in The Times, Threads had two million users in its first two hours. Two hours later, it had five million users. The next day, Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, said it had 30 million. Isaac wrote that Threads “appears to have taken the crown as the most rapidly downloaded app ever.” An independent tracker purports to show that the app is still adding about a million users per day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Where Energy Is Most Affordable
description: Wondering what air-conditioning will cost you this summer? A study compared energy costs in all 50 states and Washington, D.C.
content: Climate change is affecting energy consumption for homeowners and renters alike. Just last week, the average daily global temperatures were the hottest ever recorded (can you say “air-conditioning?”). On the flip side, the shifting climate is increasing occurrences of extremely cold, short-term weather, also adding to our total energy costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag, Raúl Vilchis and Christopher Lee
title: As Politicians Cry ‘Crisis,’ Some Migrants Are Finding Their Way
description: New York City’s leadership says housing and caring for migrants is costing billions, and “destroying” the city. But economists say their arrival will eventually be a boon.
content: At around 7 a.m. one day last August, the first migrants sent to New York City by the governor of Texas arrived with little warning on a bus, and walked sleepily into their new lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Christine Hauser
title: At Least 3 Tornados Confirmed on Wednesday in Chicago Area
description: The National Weather Service confirmed the tornadoes on Thursday after issuing warnings. Suburbs were damaged but there were no reported injuries.
content: At least three tornadoes touched down in the Chicago area late on Wednesday, damaging homes and uprooting trees, the National Weather Service and city officials confirmed on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Burton, Laura Starecheski, Julie Snyder and Carla Pallone
title: Episode 3: The Sentence
description: From Serial Productions. The patients watch as the nurse who caused their pain is sentenced.
content: The patients are still reckoning with what the pain the nurse inflicted has cost them. Now a court will decide what it should cost her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: The Brief, Dry Life of Burger King's All-Cheese ‘Burger’
description: The latest fast-food stunt to sweep the internet is the “Real Cheeseburger” from Burger King Thailand, 20 slices of American cheese on a bun with no sauce or meat.
content: Social media’s latest fast food fascination has a simple formula: one sesame burger bun plus 20 slices of American cheese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Three Decomposed Bodies Found in Colorado Campsite
description: Law enforcement officials said the campers might have been there since last year.
content: Three highly decomposed bodies of campers were found on Sunday in the Rocky Mountains in Colorado, and they might have been there since last year, law enforcement officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: F.T.C. Chair Faces Criticism in Congressional Hearing
description: Lina Khan faced more than three hours of questioning from the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee.
content: Lina Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, faced more than three hours of criticism and ridicule from Republicans in a House hearing on Thursday, as emboldened critics increasingly put pressure on the agency for its crackdown on the growing power of tech giants.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Shining a Light on Postpartum Depression
description: A psychiatrist and a new mother discuss the condition. Also: “Eco-anxiety”; domestic violence; Donald Trump’s stalling strategy; making a minyan.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Nicole Sperling
title: Once ‘The Nanny,’ Now Center Stage as the Actors’ Union Leader
description: Fran Drescher, who became a household name for her role on a 1990s sitcom, is now president of the union going on strike.
content: The stage was different, and so was the tone. But the voice was unmistakable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: The BBC Aired Saturation Coverage of Anchor’s Behavior. Was It Too Much?
description: The BBC is no ordinary media outlet and its presenter is no ordinary journalist. But the network’s wall-to-wall coverage has raised questions of its own.
content: There were urgent NATO meetings about the war in Ukraine, raging floods from India to Vermont, and a record heat wave across America. But this week the BBC wound up airing wall-to-wall coverage of a different story: itself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 13, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 13, 2023.
content: An article on Wednesday about a nonprofit that purchased newspapers in Maine misstated where the National Trust for Local News is based. It is based in Denver, not Lexington, Mass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘The Five Demands’ Review: Occupying a College for Racial Justice
description: In the wake of the Supreme Court’s decision on affirmative action, a documentary recalls the occupation of City College 50 years ago.
content: Among the wave of student protests that occurred across American university campuses in the late 1960s, the student occupation of The City College of New York in April 1969 was a highly local yet pivotal act of civil disobedience. The more than 200 Black and Puerto Rican students who occupied the buildings on South Campus for two weeks did so in protest of the school’s admissions policy and the lack of diversity in its student body. At a time when 40 percent of New York City’s high school graduates were Black or Latino, the film reports, only 9 percent of City College attendees were part of those communities. “The Five Demands,” a new documentary from Greta Schiller and Andrea Weiss, returns to the campus 50 years later alongside former students, now in their late 60s and 70s, who participated in the protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: Tubi Is Rewriting the Rules of Black Indie Movies (for Free)
description: In genre films like “Cinnamon” and “Murder City,” new voices are delivering genuine thrills with a loose energy and a generous sense of drama.
content: Over the past few years, Tubi has quietly amassed a thriving collection of Black-led independent movies. This might come as news to anyone caught in an endless scroll of Netflix offerings, but not to Tubi’s loyal and growing following. These are movies that get right to the heart of the matter, like their titles: “Watch Your Back,”  “Murder City” and “Twisted House Sitter.” In a way, they’re the latest successors to basic cable thrillers, straight-to-video, Lifetime movies, and low-budget B-cinema. But they have a loose energy and generous sense of drama all their own.

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Earth Mama’ Review: A Mother Dreams Inside a Brutal System

content: There are moments in “Earth Mama,” a drama about motherhood at its most fragile, when the movie’s quiet intensity seems to settle in your chest, as if a heavy stone had been placed over your heart. Written and directed by Savanah Leaf — this is her feature debut — the film is intimate, modestly scaled and often so outwardly unassuming that you might not at first notice its artistry. It also features one of the most expressive scenes that I’ve seen all year, one that reveals a world of heartache with a single camera movement.

author: By Walter Mosley
title: Colson Whitehead Returns to Harlem, and His Hero Returns to Crime
description: “Crook Manifesto,” set in the 1970s, finds the “Harlem Shuffle” protagonist Ray Carney drawn back into the game in order to score Jackson 5 tickets for his daughter.
content: Returning to the world of his novel “Harlem Shuffle,” Colson Whitehead’s “Crook Manifesto” is a dazzling treatise, a glorious and intricate anatomy of the heist, the con and the slow game. There’s an element of crime here, certainly, but as in Whitehead’s previous books, genre isn’t the point. Here he uses the crime novel as a lens to investigate the mechanics of a singular neighborhood at a particular tipping point in time. He has it right: the music, the energy, the painful calculus of loss. Structured into three time periods — 1971, 1973 and finally the year of America’s bicentennial celebration, 1976 — “Crook Manifesto” gleefully detonates its satire upon this world while getting to the heart of the place and its people.

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Theater Camp’ Review: Cabin Into the Woods
description: In this bitterly funny mockumentary set at a drama institute, the actors feel their characters in their bones.
content: “Acting,” the Tony winner Ben Platt opines in character, “is remembering and choosing to forget.” “Theater Camp,” a fizzy mockumentary about growing up Gershwin, does both. Platt wrote it with three longtime pals, Molly Gordon (friends since toddlerhood), Nick Lieberman (friends since high school) and his fiancé, Noah Galvin, who, like Platt, played the lead role in Broadway’s “Dear Evan Hansen.” (Gordon and Lieberman also direct the film.) These former youth performers remember everything: desperate auditions, capricious rejections and a dawning concern that one’s dreams of stage success are as flimsy as spray-painted cardboard stars. But the camp counselors the four have created — exaggerations of ones they’ve known — disregard the trauma they’ve endured, and now, inflict on others. Call it summer Stockholm syndrome. And call their group therapy session a treat.

content: Everyone else was gone: the authorities, the aid workers, the other journalists too. One week into Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the Associated Press video journalist Mstyslav Chernov was still in the port city of Mariupol, watching from a high floor of a hospital as a tank emblazoned with a white Z pulled up alongside. Smoke kept rising, bitter and black, from the shelled housing blocks a short distance away. There was no way out. Mariupol was surrounded now. Chernov kept his cameras rolling.
